Executive Summary

Introduction

Siemens Power Corporation (SPC) owns and operates a nuclear fuel fabrication facility located at 2101 Horn Rapids Road, just inside the northern boundary of the City of Richland.  The plant produces nuclear fuel bundle assemblies for light water reactors of both boiling water and pressurized water designs.  Intermediate fuel products, i.e. uranium dioxide powder and uranium dioxide fuel pellets, are also produced for use by other nuclear fuel fabricators.

Regulatory Environment

The SPC plant is licensed as a major materials licensee by the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) under their regulations in 10 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 70.  The basis for this NRC license (Special Nuclear Materials License No. SNM-1227), which SPC (and prior plant owners) have held since 1970, is the plant's possession and processing of special nuclear material in the form of low enriched uranium (less than 5% enriched in the uranium isotope U-235).  The NRC license is very comprehensive in scope and prescriptive in nature.  Via license conditions it regulates the health, safety, and environmental aspects of all of the plant's facilities, processes, and activities that deal with special nuclear material (SNM), which encompass the majority of all activities conducted on the site.  The NRC assesses SPC's compliance with the terms of its license via an inspection program emanating both from NRC headquarters in Washington D.C. and NRC's applicable regional office located in Arlington, Texas.  Under this consolidated inspection program, SPC receives approximately ten onsite inspections per year covering SPC's major environmental, safety, and health programs, e.g. radiological safety, criticality safety, environmental protection, waste management, chemical safety, emergency preparedness, security, SNM accountability, fire protection, training, and management controls.

Next to the NRC, SPC's most significant regulator is the Washington State D

epartment of Ecology (Ecology).  A substantial portion of SPC's wastes contain both chemical and radioactive constituents that require their classification as "mixed" wastes.  These mixed wastes, plus a smaller number of chemical but non-radioactive wastes, are regulated under Ecology's Dangerous Waste Regulations in WAC 173-303.  The SPC plant also sewers certain of its treated liquid effluents under the terms of a state waste discharge permit administered under Ecology's water quality regulations.  The permit limits the volume of SPC's liquid effluent as well as the amounts of key chemical constituents present in the effluent.  Both Ecology regulatory programs involve routine reporting requirements and periodic onsite inspections by Ecology staff.

SPC's possession/utilization of radionuclides other than enriched uranium is regulated by the Washington State Department of Health (WDOH) via a State Radioactive Materials License.  This primarily impacts a small service organization within SPC that performs service work at nuclear reactor sites.  The State Radioactive Materials License also regulates SPC's usage of sealed radiation sources of a sort contained in measuring, testing, and calibration equipment.  WDOH also provides regulatory oversight over airborne emissions from radioactive material processing systems.  Compliance with WDOH regulations/licenses is confirmed via periodic onsite inspections by WDOH personnel.
The industrial health and safety aspects of SPC's activities are regulated under Washington State Department of Labor and Industries (L&I) regulations in WAC 296-24 (General Safety and Health Standards), WAC 296-62 (General Occupational Health Standards) and, as applicable, WAC 296-155 (Safety Standards for Construction Work).  SPC is also subject to, and has instituted a program in response to, L&I's regulations in WAC 296-67, Safety Standards for Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.  These regulations are equivalent to the Feder

al OSHA process safety management regulations (29 CFR 1910.119).

On a local governmental level, the SPC plant is regulated by the Benton Clean Air Authority and the City of Richland.  The Clean Air Authority regulates SPC's airborne emission sources, primarily via their source registration/permit program.  The City regulates SPC's sewer discharges via their sewer pre-treatment regulations.

SPC Regulatory Compliance and Environmental Protection Policies

SPC Policy Guide 10.1 states that it is the policy of SPC "to conduct its operations such that they will not be detrimental to its employees, the public, or the environment."  This involves compliance with the "conditions of all applicable licenses, permits, and regulations;" in addition, "appropriate regard will be given to regulatory guides and industry standards."  Policy Guide 10.1 assigns ultimate responsibility for adherence to this policy to the Senior Vice President and General Manager, SPC.

SPC Policy Guide 10.4 deals specifically with compliance with environmental laws, requiring that "all of its operations shall be in full compliance with Federal and State environmental laws and regulations and local ordinances."  Furthermore, the policy states that "it shall be the preferred position that process and equipment designs and operations take into account and mitigate any potential adverse impact on the environs from any hazardous matter generated or used by SPC-ND such that the requirement for administrative controls is minimized."

Key to understanding the Richland fuel fabrication facilities approach to environmental compliance is that it is not the sole responsibility of the "environmental compliance staff."  SPC Policy Guide 10.4 states clearly that the Senior Vice President and General Manager of SPC has the "ultimate responsibility for compliance with environmental laws and for assuring that adequate resources are available to support compliance."  On a day-to-day basis, environmental compliance is a

chieved by a partnership between key operating and support groups onsite.  Those groups, each with their responsibilities for environmental compliance defined in SPC Policy Guide 10.4, include Finance; Safety, Security and Licensing (Regulatory Compliance); Plant Operations; Manufacturing Engineering; Materials and Purchasing; Traffic and Warehousing; and generically, all managers and supervisors.  Environmental compliance, therefore, is a line management function distributed throughout the facility.

SPC Organizational Responsibilities for Accident Prevention/Environmental Compliance

As discussed above, SPC's accident prevention and environmental protection programs stem from a top-level policy of compliance with all applicable health, safety, and environmental regulations and the clear assignment of line management responsibilities to assure that compliance is achieved.  From a practical standpoint, SPC has established a management organization/structure to implement its compliance initiatives.  Individual organizations conduct their activities, including their compliance-related activities, via established policies, procedures, and other formal written guidance.

Virtually all of the activities conducted onsite at SPC's Richland facility that pose potentially significant operational health, safety, or environmental risks are conducted within the Manufacturing Division, headed by the Vice President, Manufacturing.  Within the Manufacturing Division, the Safety, Security, and Licensing (SS&L) Department includes the Regulatory Compliance Section, responsible for review of regulations for potential applicability to SPC, dissemination of regulatory requirements to affected organizations, and assessment of regulatory compliance status.  Technical safety professionals in the disciplines of environmental protection, industrial hygiene, SNM accountability, hazardous materials transportation, and licensing work in the Regulatory Compliance Section.  The balance of the te

chnical safety professionals work within the Safety Section of SS&L.  These include staff responsible for SPC's criticality safety, health physics, radiological protection, industrial safety, emergency preparedness, and fire protection programs.

SS&L staff incorporate health, safety, and environmental requirements from applicable regulations, licenses, and permits into internal safety standards.  The top level document for these internal standards is EMF-30, the SPC Safety Manual.  EMF-30 is organized into six chapters as follows: Chapter 1, Industrial Safety Standards; Chapter 2, Radiological Safety Standards; Chapter 3, Criticality Safety Standards; Chapter 4, Environmental Safety Standards; Chapter 5, Radioactive Material Shipping Standards; and Chapter 6, Industrial Hygiene Safety Standards.  Requirements for lower tier safety-related documentation, e.g. criticality safety analyses, radiation work procedures, etc. are generally defined in EMF-30 safety standards.  EMF-32, SPC Emergency Plan and Procedures, is also maintained by SS&L and constitutes the top tier document that defines and governs SPC's overall emergency preparedness and emergency response program.  SS&L's program of environmental, safety, and health audits and inspections is set forth in EMF-1733, Richland Fuel Manufacturing Administrative Procedures.  This internal audit/inspection program currently establishes a total of 42 distinct audits and inspections, with frequencies ranging from monthly to triennially.

The second department within the Manufacturing Division with a major role in SPC's accident prevention/environmental compliance effort is the Manufacturing Engineering Department.  The Manufacturing Engineering Department is responsible for the construction, modification, and maintenance of plant facilities; the design, installation, maintenance, and modification of plant process equipment; the conduct of routine calibration and preventive maintenance programs on plant equipment and instr

uments, including safety equipment and systems; and the conduct of comprehensive process, chemical, and fire hazards analyses on plant processing systems with a potential for significant adverse health, safety or environmental impacts.  Manufacturing Engineering's activities pertinent to plant safety are typically defined in EMF-858, Manufacturing Engineering Procedures and Practices, or in sub-tier documentation identified in EMF-858 procedures.

The third department within the Manufacturing Division with a major role in accident prevention and environmental protection at the SPC plant site is the Plant Operations Department.  The Plant Operations Department, as its name implies, operates essentially all of SPC's manufacturing processes.  This includes the receipt of incoming feed materials and supplies, the manufacturing of fuel-related products (powder, pellets, assemblies), and the preparation of finished products for offsite shipment.  All Plant Operations production activities are covered by standard operating procedures (SOPs).  Personnel are trained and qualified to the SOPs via a formally implemented and documented training program.

Key Elements of SPC's Accident Prevention/Environmental Compliance Programs

SPC's accident prevention and environmental compliance programs are fully integrated into day-to-day plant operations and, as noted above, are formally documented in policies, standards, and procedures.  Certain safety program elements and plant practices however are judged to be key to the prevention of accidental chemical releases that could pose significant adverse impacts to workers, the public, or the environment.  A summary listing of these program elements and plant practices is provided below.  It should be noted that the listing is summary in nature; it does not include all elements of SPC's safety efforts nor does it fully describe those elements that it does list.

1. Project Objectives - Documented process to provide multi-disciplinary review and approval (Safety, Engineering, Operations) of proposed plant projects.  Includes consideration of safety and environmental factors.  
2. Technical Design Bases/ Criteria - Documented process to provide multi-disciplinary review and approval (Safety, Engineering, Operations) of the technical design bases and criteria of major proposed plant projects.  Addresses safety and environmental issues associated with the project.
3. As-Built Drawings - Established process to assure generation and maintenance of up-to-date as-built engineering drawings for plant process systems.
4. Configuration Management - Highly controlled, reviewed, and documented process used to manage the installation of, or modification to, plant equipment, facilities, controls, and services.  Provides for multi-disciplinary review/approval for initial change authorization, startup approval, and final acceptance.  Provides significant emphasis on safety/environmental aspects.
5. Acceptance Testing - Documented process to govern acceptance testing of new or modified facilities, services, or equipment.  Addresses applicable safety-related issues and requires multi-disciplinary review and approval.
6. Startup Council - Formal council review protocol to review the nuclear safety, radiological, environmental, industrial safety, and licensing implications of the proposed startup of new facilities or existing facilities having undergone major modifications.  Involves multi-disciplinary review/approval with final sign-off by V.P., Manufacturing.
7. Hazards Analysis - Provides for comprehensive hazards analyses of plant systems with a potential for significant adverse health, safety, or environmental impacts.  Defines the SPC protocol for hazards analyses being conducted to comply with the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and USEPA Risk Management Program Standard (40 CFR 68).
8. Instrument Repetiti

ve Maintenance - Formal computer-based program to assure the periodic calibration of plant instruments.  Includes instruments used to monitor/control safety-related process parameters. 
9. Preventive Maintenance - Formal computer-based program to assure the routine application of preventive maintenance activities to plant equipment, facilities, systems, and support activities.  Includes preventive maintenance activities on safety-related equipment and systems.
10. Hazards Analysis/Safety Review - Procedure defining requirements for hazards analyses and safety reviews as applied to SPC's facilities and operations.
11. OSHA PSM/EPA RMP Program - Procedure defining SPC's overall program to meet OSHA Process Safety Management rule (29 CFR 1910.119 and WAC 296-67) and EPA Risk Management Program rule (40 CFR 68).
12. Bulk Chemical Loading and Unloading - Procedure establishing SPC's safety controls as applied to the loading and unloading of bulk liquid chemicals.
13. Spill and Decontamination Program for Hazardous Wastes and Substances - Procedure defining SPC's approach to responding to spills of hazardous waste and substances, including identification, risk assessment, spill control, decontamination, and waste disposal.
14. Chemical Release Reporting - Procedure defining SPC's actions to assure proper regulatory reporting of chemical releases. 
15. Flammable and Combustible Liquids/Solids Storage and Handling - Procedure defining requirements at SPC related to storage and handling of flammable and combustible materials.
16. General Chemical Storage and Handling - Procedure defining SPC requirements relative to general storage and handling of chemicals.
17. Compressed Gases Handling and Storage - Procedure defining SPC practices related to the handling and storage of compressed gases.
18. Fire Protection Program - Procedure defining standards and guidelines for SPC's fire protection program.  
19. Radiation Protection Program - Standards defining SPC's program to conduc

t its radioactive materials processes in a manner that is fully protective of workers, the public, and the environment and fully compliant with applicable regulations.
20. Criticality Safety Program - Standards defining SPC's program to conduct its fissile material operations in a manner that precludes accidental criticalities.
21. Environmental Protection Program - Standards defining SPC's program to conduct its operations in a manner that minimizes adverse environmental impacts and fully complies with applicable regulations, licenses, and permits.
22. Radioactive Material Shipping Program - Standards defining SPC's program to conducts its radioactive material shipping operations in a manner that fully complies with applicable transportation regulations.
23. Industrial Hygiene Program - Standards establishing SPC's industrial hygiene program aimed at managing (recognizing, evaluating, and controlling) workplace chemical and physical hazards.
24. Emergency Preparedness Program - SPC's comprehensive program of preparedness for, and response to, operational emergencies.  Includes procedures governing event classification, emergency notifications, protective action recommendations, offsite agency interactions, emergency response/mitigation, and public information.
25. Pre-Emergency Plan - A document provided to the local (Richland) fire department providing facility-by-facility information pertinent to develop a plan of attack on a fire, chemical spill, or other emergency in a given building or facility.  Provides information on building size, construction, occupancy, radioactive and hazardous materials inventory, HVAC system, and fire protection equipment.
26. Environmental, Health and Safety Council - A senior management council meeting on a monthly basis to receive briefings from technical safety/environmental personnel on current issues/progress/problems related to all major SPC health, safety, and environmental programs.
27. ALARA Committee - Standing committee of

key management and technical staff focusing on maintaining health and environmental impacts from SPC operations to a level "as low as reasonably achievable." 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  
Overview of Current Plant Facilities and Operations

The SPC nuclear fuel fabrication facility in Richland, Washington produces enriched uranium nuclear fuel for use in commercial light water reactors of both boiling water and pressurized water design.  Finished fuel assemblies (bundles) are supplied to nuclear utilities for direct usage as fuel in their nuclear power reactors, however intermediate products such as enriched uranium powder or pellets are also produced in behalf of other nuclear fuel cycle facilities.

The typical feed material to the plant is uranium hexafluoride (UF6) received in 30-inch diameter steel cylinders, each containing approximately 1500 kilograms of enriched uranium.  The UF6 is chemically converted to uranium dioxide (UO2) powder, which is pressed into fuel pellets, which in turn are subsequently loaded into fuel rods.  These loaded fuel rods, in conjunction with other supporting hardware (tie plates and grid spacers), are assembled into a variety of fuel bundle designs, depending on the customer-specific requirements.

The chemical conversion technology utilized at SPC for the UF6 to UO2 conversion relies on a "dry" conversion process that accomplishes the UF6 to UO2 conversion in a single-stage, vapor-phase reactor.  The dry conversion process produces a comparatively small volume liquid waste stream, with nearly all of the fluorides in the reactor offgas stream being condensed to produce a marketable hydrofluoric acid (HF) byproduct.  This technology is housed in the new Dry Conversion Facility (DCF) that was brought on-line over 1997/1998.  

Production

of UO2 can also be achieved via an aqueous ("wet") process which produces an ammonia-based uranium intermediate, ammonium diuranate (ADU).  The ADU process produces relatively large quantities of ammonia - and fluoride - containing liquid wastes that are processed for ammonia and uranium recovery in separate wastewater treatment facilities.  The dry conversion process has replaced the ADU process for all UF6 to UO2 conversion; use of the ADU process is now limited to the wet recycle of off-specification or impure ("dirty") UO2 powder or pellets ("uranium scrap").  This recent transition from the ADU process to dry conversion as SPC's primary chemical conversion technology has markedly reduced the amount of liquid and solid wastes produced from these activities.

The primary fuel production and support activities occur onsite at a number of key facilities.  The most significant of those facilities are as follows:

Dry Conversion Facility - This major operating facility houses three parallel conversion lines which utilize the dry conversion technology to convert UF6 to UO2.  UO2 powder produced in the Dry Conversion Facility is transferred to the UO2 Building for subsequent processing steps (pellet pressing, grinding, rod loading, bundle assembly).  Alternatively, dry conversion powder may be transferred to the Specialty Fuels Building for incorporation into neutron absorber fuel.  The Dry Conversion Facility also includes equipment for the recovery of fluorides (as hydrofluoric acid) from the dry conversion offgas stream.  The acid is temporarily stored in sample tanks in the facility before being transferred to large outdoor storage tanks.  The recovered hydrofluoric acid is ultimately sold as a commercial chemical product.

Uranium Dioxide (UO2) Building - This major operating facility houses the ADU conversion line, pelletizing, pellet sintering, rod loading, and bundle assembly.  Other related activities/facilities include scrap recovery facilities, the Miscella

neous Uranium Recovery System (MURS), the Powder Storage Facility, and various laboratory facilities.

Specialty Fuels (SF) Building - This major operating facility produces uranium fuel pellets containing the neutron poison gadolinium (neutron absorber fuel, or NAF).  After blending UO2 powder (received from the Dry Conversion Facility or UO2 Building) with gadolinia (an oxide of gadolinium), processing proceeds much the same as in the UO2 Building (powder preparation, pelletizing, etc.).  The SF Building also houses the Solid Waste Uranium Recovery (SWUR) Facility, where uranium is thermally recovered from non-dangerous, uranium-containing combustible wastes.

Engineering Laboratory Operations (ELO) Building - The ELO Building is a combination facility housing production, engineering testing/development, laboratory, and office activities.  The production process is the Gadolinium Scrap Uranium Recovery (GSUR) process used to remove gadolinia and other impurities from various uranium feed streams to produce uranyl nitrate solution for subsequent conversion to UO2 via the ADU process in the UO2 Bldg.  Since GSUR is a solvent extraction process, the facility is also often referred to as the Solvent Extraction, or SX, Facility.

Machine Shop - The Machine Shop fabricates rod end caps, spacers, and tie plates used as component hardware in the fabrication of fuel bundles.  Once fabricated, these stainless steel and zircaloy components are chemically treated in the Component Etch Facility.  The Machine Shop also performs traditional machining services in support of plant operations.

Ammonia Recovery Facility (ARF) - The ARF is a key waste management facility which provides several recycling/treatment functions relative to SPC's liquid effluent streams.  Most important of these functions is the recovery of ammonium hydroxide from ADU conversion effluents and other stored ammonia-containing liquid wastes.  This recovered ammonium hydroxide meets 100 percent of the ammoniu

m hydroxide needs for the ADU conversion lines; excess recovered ammonium hydroxide is sold for eventual use as agricultural fertilizer.  Also housed in ARF is the Lagoon 5A Ion Exchange (IX) Column, which recovers residual uranium from the Lagoon 5A outfall to sewer.

Lagoon Uranium Recovery (LUR) Facility - The LUR Facility houses a chemical process for the recovery of uranium from Lagoon 3, a surface impoundment which receives and stores high uranium liquid effluents.  The LUR product is further processed in other onsite production processes, with the recovered uranium being eventually used for fuel pellet production.

Solids Processing Facility (SPF) - The SPF is a companion facility to LUR and is used to recover uranium from solids in SPC's surface impoundment system.  The SPF provides for surface impoundment solids retrieval, dissolution, separation, and solids dewatering and packaging.  The dissolved uranium in the liquid phase is recovered at the LUR facility.

Regulated Substances Utilized

Substances meeting the criteria for regulation under the EPA Risk Management Program regulations at SPC's Richland fuel fabrication facility include anhydrous ammonia, ammonium hydroxide >20%, and propane.  A brief overview of the usage of each of these chemicals follows.

Anhydrous Ammonia

Anhydrous ammonia is stored onsite in two 6,500 gallon tanks.  It is piped to one of four ammonia dissociators where it is catalytically cracked into hydrogen (H2) and nitrogen (N2) gases.  The H2/N2 mixture is utilized as a cover gas in several plant processes, including the dry conversion reactors, the powder calciners, and the pellet sintering furnaces.

Ammonium Hydroxide >20%

Ammonium hydroxide >20% (at SPC, not exceeding approximately 23%) is stored in one 28,000 gallon tank and two 10,000 gallon tanks.  The ammonium hydroxide is pumped to the UO2 Building where it is added to the precipitation tank in the ammonium diuranate (ADU) conversion process to form an ADU precipitate.

Once separated from the ADU solids via centrifugation, the liquid waste effluent from the ADU process, containing ammonium nitrate and excess ammonium hydroxide, is routed first to a covered surface impoundment, and then to the Ammonia Recovery Facility (ARF).  ARF, via caustic addition and subsequent steam stripping in a distillation column, recovers ammonium hydroxide and returns it to tank storage.  ARF is also recovering ammonium hydroxide from liquids that have been in long term storage in SPC's surface impoundment system.  This recovered ammonium hydroxide is also returned to tank storage.  Since SPC's ammonium hydroxide recovery efforts are producing more ammonium hydroxide than is needed in the ADU conversion process, SPC sells excess ammonium hydroxide for use as an agricultural fertilizer.

Propane

Propane is stored onsite in 1000 gallon tanks.  The four interconnected tanks on the east side of the UO2 Building supply flame curtains used to burn off any hydrogen gas escaping from the ends of the pellet sintering furnaces.  Propane from these tanks is also utilized to fill fork lift trucks.  Five interconnected tanks located west of the Specialty Fuels Building supply combustion gas for the Solid Waste Uranium Recovery (SWUR) process located in the SF Building.

Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

Worst-Case for Anhydrous Ammonia - The scenario is that one of the 6,500 gallon tanks fails and drains along with 1000 feet of 1.5" diameter piping (92 gal).  An administrative control limiting tank filling to 85% (sight gauge reads % full) makes the total spilled 5,617 gallons.  Using the EPA RMP compliance manual for a 10 minute release of 27,000 pounds, a wind speed of 1.5 m/sec, an atmospheric stability class F, and a rural topography, the endpoint is 5.30 miles.  This scenario would affect a residential population of 37,630.  Tank failure is not likely because the tanks are on periodic State pressure vessel inspection for a maximum of 250 PSIG an

d even on a 100+ degree day, tank pressure is only 150 PSIG.  Each tank has dual pressure relief valves that are on a preventative maintenance program.  The tanks are guarded by concrete barriers and have metal guarding around all piping.

Alternative Release for Anhydrous Ammonia

The scenario is that a tank leaks 5,617 gallons over a 60 minute time period.  The end point is 0.87 miles and there is no residential population within that distance.

Worst-Case for Ammonium Hydroxide >20%

The scenario is that the 28,000 gallon tank is pumped to a 10,000 gallon tank that is already full.  The 28,000 gallons will overflow into the 10,000 gallon tank containment area but before overflowing that basin, the liquid overflows back to the basin surrounding the 28,000 gallon tank via a line that connects the two basins.  The spill is contained in the two basins with a surface area of 2,551 ft2.  The endpoint for this scenario is 0.81 miles and no residential population is within that distance.  This scenario is not likely to happen because the filling is started manually (if the small tank were full, overflow would be detected), then monitored by computer in a control room.  There is also a high level shutoff at 9,000 gallons.  It would take ~1.5 hours to fill the small basin and for overflow into the large basin to begin.  Routine area walk throughs would likely detect the overflow before it overflowed to the large basin, thereby limiting the surface area and endpoint of the spill.

Alternative Release for Ammonium Hydroxide >20%

The scenario is that the 28,000 gallon tank is being pumped to a 10,000 gallon tank and overflows that tank.  In this scenario the spill is discovered and stopped before overflow of the basin back into the large basin surrounding the 28,000 gallon tank, thus limiting the surface area to 811 ft2.  The endpoint is 0.19 miles and does not extend off site.

Worst-Case for Propane

The scenario is that five 1000 gallon tanks that are interconnected leak

their entire contents (21,000 lbs.).  This material is then involved in a vapor cloud explosion (10% involvement).  The distance to a 1 PSI endpoint is 0.22 miles which does not extend offsite.

Alternative Release for Propane

The scenario is that the same 21,000 lbs is released and only 3% is involved in a vapor cloud explosion.  The distance to a 1 PSI endpoint is 0.13 miles, which does not extend offsite.

Five-Year Accident History

SPC has not had an accident in the last five years that involved the release of a RMP-regulated chemical resulting in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite; or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

SPC Emergency Response Program

The SPC Emergency Response Organization consists of the Plant Emergency Response Management Team (PERMT) and the Plant Emergency Response Team (PERT) assisted by the Joint Information Center (JIC).  PERMT is controlled by the Plant Emergency Director (PED) and is responsible for classifying all declared emergency incidents and notifying applicable local, county, state, and federal agencies.  PERT is controlled by the Incident Commander, who is located at the scene of the incident and, in concert with the local fire department, is responsible for mitigating all emergency incidents.  The JIC jointly provides information and updates along with local, state and federal agencies to the media and public about all emergency incidents.  PERMT and JIC members receive annual training in their duties and also participate in an annual Table Top or Full Field Exercise every year.  PERT members receive over 24 hours of annual training in Fire Fighting, Advanced First Aid/Mass Casualties, Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus, Field Sampling, Hazardous Materials Spill Control and Decontamination Procedures.  PERT members also participate in various drills during the year and a Biennial Full Field Exercise every other year.  SPC provides i

mmediate notification and PAR's to all neighbors within one mile of the site plus local county, state and federal agencies per SPC's Emergency Plan requirements.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

SPC has extensively evaluated the safety of its anhydrous ammonia and ammonium hydroxide systems during the conduct of the Process Safety Management/Risk Management Program hazards analyses for these systems.  Safety enhancements identified via these efforts are pursued as appropriate.  As previously noted, SPC's emergency preparedness program involves training drills with state, county, and local emergency agencies which include response to and mitigation of potential accidents with these chemicals.  Critiques from the training drills are used to improve training, response coordination with agencies, public notification, and the overall effectiveness of all aspects of the emergency response program.
